awd_titl_txt: Using Targeted Constructivist Instructional Modules to Increase Undergraduate Students' Confidence, Knowledge, and Skills in Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSI) Program, this Track 2 project will develop constructivist instructional modules that help students learn mathematics through interdisciplinary, open-ended mathematical problems. Teaching mathematics via a constructivist approach may not only help students learn mathematical concepts and skills, but also gain confidence in doing mathematics. By increasing student success in mathematics, this project seeks to increase the number of students enrolling in STEM degree programs. Many students in open-access colleges need support to develop the mathematics knowledge and skills needed to progress in a STEM program.  This project seeks to identify the key mathematical concepts and skills needed for success in both college mathematics courses and in the workforce. The project will develop stand-alone instructional modules that teach mathematical topics through active student engagement in mathematics. Since each instructional module will be complete and independent, the modules have the potential to complement lower-level mathematics courses in a variety of instructional settings.

The project seeks to increase the number of declared pre-STEM majors persisting into credit-bearing STEM courses. The project will complete a pilot test to design constructivist instructional modules that both develop mathematical concepts and reinforce application skills needed for success in subsequent mathematics courses. The modules will include open-ended problems and activities that require students to justify and present solutions, which are also skills desired by potential employers. The project will assess the impact of the constructivist instructional modules and associated support activities on student learning outcomes and course completions. The project will also investigate the impact of the modules and support activities on the ability for students to apply mathematical knowledge in new situations. The project seeks to develop materials that could be shared with other institutions seeking to enhance student learning and completion of lower-level mathematics courses. The HSI Program aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI Program will also generate new knowledge on how to achieve these aims.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project designed, developed and tested activities, explorations and assessments intended to improve student retention and success in developmental math courses as taught at two year colleges. It was hoped that implementing these methods would reduce the number of students who dropped out of college before starting on college credit bearing STEM courses.

Five 'Keystone' topics in Math were identified as being crucial for student success in later Math & Science courses and complete instructional modules for teaching these topics at pre-Algebra and introductory Algebra levels were generated. A series of approaches and activities to produce a classroom environment conducive to succesfully using these materials was also produced. Documentation was produced for classroom use and facilitation notes and suggestions for the instructor to offer suggestions on how to implement these materials in the classroom were also written.

The classroom approach used was based on curricula previously developed with NSF Funding.  The approach had demonstrated success in Middle Schools and High Schools, but the available instructional materials were all targeted on students in the 10-15 age range and were unsuitable for use with the young adult population typically encountered in 2 year colleges. The project used the teaching approach of exploration, concept building and skill reinforcement developed in those earlier curricula but set the activities in contexts more representative of the interests of young adults.

All materials developed were tested in classrooms at the University of New Mexico, Taos Branch and results were encouraging.

The students taking these classes had all experienced little success in math courses during their experiences in their K-12 school systems and some of the students were math phobic.

However the students using the new course modules demonstrated improved pass rates and higher retention in subsequent math courses compared to those in traditional math courses. The modules were also noted to enhance student engagement and understanding of key mathematical concepts, which helped build confidence and preparedness for STEM pathways. After taking the module classes, students tended to have a more positive attitude towards math compared to the attitude they had before starting the class. The students appreciated the more sophisticated content of the modules and their reaction to the modules was positive.

The Keystone modules went through some iterations during their development and amongst the lessons learned by the team during that process were:

  • to be accessible to the students in these courses, the reading level needs to be 8th/9th grade level.
  • consistent with that, the activities need to be ‘chunked’ into smaller, more manageable pieces compared the text and structure originally trialed.
  • the heavy science scenario used in one of the blocks in a module was less popular compared to more familiar everyday contexts (hiking, making coffee, COVID infection rates etc.)

Additionally there were some additional unanticipated ‘soft’ benefits to the institution:

  • Implementation of the Keystone activities led the instructors to revamping other aspects of their courses.
  • Instructors also find it rewarding to use materials contextualized to adult student interests.
  • When questioned about sustainability, each of the instructors using the modules will continue to use them when teaching the appropriate courses.
  • Overall, the program led to improved camaraderie and communication within the Math department, and general and lasting changes to faculty members approach to teaching their developmental math courses
  • The engagement and commitment of faculty to educational research and curriculum development made the institution attractive to some new hires.

This was a pilot level program and it would be beneficial to test these methods across multiple institutions with a significantly larger number of students and with a wider range of demographics than were present in Taos’ semirural, mostly low income and mostly Hispanic community.
